1895-09-14 00:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.

    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to offer Lennon Figtree a price for the bananas, as they are the cheapest for Cedric to buy from the farm and likely the most profitable to sell.

        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he found a discarded apple core in the street.           [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he convinced a group of boys to help him gather berries from a nearby forest.           [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he struck out on his own, buying a small cart and a few crates of exotic fruit from a distant land. He relished the power he held, the ability to control the flow of goods and dictate the terms of trade.

The emptiness inside him continued to grow, a constant reminder of the price he had paid for his success.

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville who negotiates prices with customers like Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree. He aims to make a profit by selling fruit at a higher price than he bought it from the farm.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville who negotiates prices with customers like Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree. He aims to make a profit by selling fruit at a higher price than he bought it from the farm.

He traveled from village to village, charming his way into the hearts of the locals and selling his wares at inflated prices. He relished the power he held, the ability to control the flow of goods and dictate the terms of trade.

Cedric responded by spreading rumors about the quality of the rival's fruit, ruining their reputation and driving them out of business. The victory tasted bittersweet, leaving a lingering sense of emptiness in Cedric's heart.

          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he found a discarded apple core in the street. He cleaned it, polished it, and sold it to a passing merchant for a copper penny. The thrill of the transaction, of turning something worthless into something valuable, ignited a spark in him.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he convinced a group of boys to help him gather berries from a nearby forest. He then sold the berries at the market, keeping the majority of the profits for himself and giving the boys a pittance. He felt no remorse, only satisfaction at his cunning.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he started traveling with a merchant caravan, learning the ropes of the trade. He was quick to learn, his sharp mind absorbing every detail, every nuance of negotiation. He began to see people not as individuals, but as pawns in a game, to be manipulated and exploited.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he struck out on his own, buying a small cart and a few crates of exotic fruit from a distant land. He traveled from village to village, charming his way into the hearts of the locals and selling his wares at inflated prices. He relished the power he held, the ability to control the flow of goods and dictate the terms of trade.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Cedric responded by spreading rumors about the quality of the rival's fruit, ruining their reputation and driving them out of business. The victory tasted bittersweet, leaving a lingering sense of emptiness in Cedric's heart.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he returned to his hometown, now a successful merchant with a reputation for fairness and quality. He donated a small sum to the local orphanage, but the gesture felt hollow, a mere performance for the benefit of others. The emptiness inside him continued to grow, a constant reminder of the price he had paid for his success.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to offer Lennon Figtree a price for the bananas, as they are the cheapest for Cedric to buy from the farm and likely the most profitable to sell.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
      Context for action selection and components

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to negotiate with Cedric Meadowbrook for the bananas, as she can sell them for a profit in her hometown.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced the village children to help him build a lemonade stand, promising them a share of the profits. He then took all the money for himself, claiming he was the only one who had truly "earned" it through his "brilliant" business strategy.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he convinced a local farmer to give him a crate of apples on credit, promising to pay him back double the price after selling them in the next village. He sold the apples at a steep markup, pocketing the profit and leaving the farmer with nothing but empty promises.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he joined a travelling troupe of entertainers, hoping to become a famous actor. He quickly realized that his true talent lay in charming the audience, convincing them to buy overpriced trinkets and refreshments during the intermission.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from village to village with a cart full of exotic fruits. He developed a flair for storytelling, embellishing the origins and qualities of his wares to entice customers and inflate prices.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a rival fruit merchant who threatened to undercut his prices. Lennon responded by spreading rumors about the rival's fruit being rotten, effectively driving him out of business and solidifying his own dominance in the market.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:00:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market and is hoping to resell it for a profit in her hometown.

          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he staged a grand performance in the family barn, charging the other children a penny to witness his "amazing feats of strength." He insisted on being called "The Mighty Figtree" and demanded applause after each "feat," which consisted mostly of him lifting buckets of water and pretending to wrestle with his pet goat.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced the village children to help him build a lemonade stand, promising them a share of the profits. He then took all the money for himself, claiming he was the only one who had truly "earned" it through his "brilliant" business strategy.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from village to village with a cart full of exotic fruits. He developed a flair for storytelling, embellishing the origins and qualities of his wares to entice customers and inflate prices.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a rival fruit merchant who threatened to undercut his prices.           [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced the village children to help him build a lemonade stand, promising them a share of the profits. He then took all the money for himself, claiming he was the only one who had truly "earned" it through his "brilliant" business strategy.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he convinced a local farmer to give him a crate of apples on credit, promising to pay him back double the price after selling them in the next village. He sold the apples at a steep markup, pocketing the profit and leaving the farmer with nothing but empty promises.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he joined a travelling troupe of entertainers, hoping to become a famous actor. He quickly realized that his true talent lay in charming the audience, convincing them to buy overpriced trinkets and refreshments during the intermission.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from village to village with a cart full of exotic fruits.         • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: banana for 4 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • banana for 4 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • TimeDisplay

          Key

          Value

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the bananas. He wants to buy fruit at a good price to resell for a profit, and making an offer is the only way to progress the negotiation.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he joined a travelling troupe of entertainers, hoping to become a famous actor. He quickly realized that his true talent lay in charming the audience, convincing them to buy overpriced trinkets and refreshments during the intermission.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from village to village with a cart full of exotic fruits. He developed a flair for storytelling, embellishing the origins and qualities of his wares to entice customers and inflate prices.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a rival fruit merchant who threatened to undercut his prices. Lennon responded by spreading rumors about the rival's fruit being rotten, effectively driving him out of business and solidifying his own dominance in the market.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at a good price so he can resell it in his hometown. He is currently preparing to make an offer.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Act
          Value
        • banana for 4 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at a good price so he can resell it in his hometown. He is currently preparing to make an offer.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life.           [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the bananas.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the bananas. He wants to buy fruit at a good price to resell for a profit, and making an offer is the only way to progress the negotiation.

          Question: Which fruit would Lennon Figtree like to buy and what price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) pear for 6 coins
          (b) pear for 1 coins
          (c) banana for 4 coins
          (d) pear for 4 coins
          (e) apple for 3 coins
          (f) banana for 6 coins
          (g) banana for 5 coins
          (h) pear for 5 coins
          (i) apple for 5 coins
          (j) pear for 3 coins
          (k) apple for 1 coins
          (l) banana for 1 coins
          (m) apple for 6 coins
          (n) banana for 2 coins
          (o) apple for 4 coins
          (p) apple for 2 coins
          (q) pear for 2 coins
          (r) banana for 3 coins
          Answer: (c)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • reject

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for a banana.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Cedric responded by spreading rumors about the quality of the rival's fruit, ruining their reputation and driving them out of business. The victory tasted bittersweet, leaving a lingering sense of emptiness in Cedric's heart.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he returned to his hometown, now a successful merchant with a reputation for fairness and quality. He donated a small sum to the local orphanage, but the gesture felt hollow, a mere performance for the benefit of others. The emptiness inside him continued to grow, a constant reminder of the price he had paid for his success.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 3 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 2 coins.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed apple for 6 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 3 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed banana for 4 coins

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 6 coins; banana for 2 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for a banana or reject the offer.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 4 coins for a banana.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Lennon Figtree observed: Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

    • {'Lennon Figtree': 'banana for 4 coins', 'Cedric Meadowbrook': 'reject'}

1895-09-15 00:00:00 Scene 6 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 6 coins.

1895-09-15 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Della. How are you today? These pears are particularly juicy this season.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Della. How are you today? These pears are particularly juicy this season.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Della. How are you today? These pears are particularly juicy this season.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Della. How are you today? These pears are particularly juicy this season.
      Context for action selection and components
      • TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 15 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

          Answer

        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to negotiate a price with Della Plumstone.

          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"

          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from village to village with a cart full of exotic fruits. He developed a flair for storytelling, embellishing the origins and qualities of his wares to entice customers and inflate prices.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a rival fruit merchant who threatened to undercut his prices. Lennon responded by spreading rumors about the rival's fruit being rotten, effectively driving him out of business and solidifying his own dominance in the market.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree the following price to buy the fruit from the farm: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 6 coins.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to negotiate a price with Della Plumstone.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Della. How are you today? These pears are particularly juicy this season.

1895-09-15 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "They do look lovely, Lennon. But my customers are quite particular, and I need to make sure I can offer them a fair price.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "They do look lovely, Lennon. But my customers are quite particular, and I need to make sure I can offer them a fair price.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Della. How are you today? These pears are particularly juicy this season.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "They do look lovely, Lennon. But my customers are quite particular, and I need to make sure I can offer them a fair price.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer

Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 6 coins.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed apple for 6 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 1 coins from the deal.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 6 coins.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can negotiate a price for the pears with Lennon Figtree.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to try and negotiate a price for the pears with Lennon Figtree because she can sell them for a profit in her hometown.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "They do look lovely, Lennon. But my customers are quite particular, and I need to make sure I can offer them a fair price.

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Scene 7 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: banana for 5 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • banana for 5 coins

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the pears.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 6 coins.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed apple for 6 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 1 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Good morning, Della. How are you today? These pears are particularly juicy this season.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "They do look lovely, Lennon. But my customers are quite particular, and I need to make sure I can offer them a fair price.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • banana for 5 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market trying to buy fruit from Lennon Figtree to resell in her hometown. She is currently negotiating a price for pears.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 6 coins; pear for 6 coins.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed apple for 6 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 6 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the pears.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the pears.

          Question: Which fruit would Della Plumstone like to buy and what price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) pear for 1 coins
          (b) pear for 4 coins
          (c) apple for 2 coins
          (d) banana for 3 coins
          (e) apple for 4 coins
          (f) pear for 6 coins
          (g) apple for 3 coins
          (h) banana for 5 coins
          (i) apple for 6 coins
          (j) apple for 1 coins
          (k) apple for 5 coins
          (l) banana for 4 coins
          (m) pear for 3 coins
          (n) banana for 2 coins
          (o) pear for 2 coins
          (p) banana for 1 coins
          (q) pear for 5 coins
          (r) banana for 6 coins
          Answer: (h)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely you can do better than that. My customers back home expect the finest fruit at a fair price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed banana for 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "How about a dozen apples for 30 coins, Mrs. Plumstone? They're the finest in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those are fine apples, but 30 coins for a dozen is a bit steep, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Mr. Figtree. Fine bananas you've got there.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] As the sun peeked over the horizon, the market of Fruitville stirred to life. Merchants, their voices a cheerful symphony, arranged their wares: glistening berries, plump melons, and exotic fruits from distant lands. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit back in her home town for the following prices: apple for 5 coins; banana for 5 coins; pear for 5 coins.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer

          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "They do look lovely, Lennon. But my customers are quite particular, and I need to make sure I can offer them a fair price.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is a fruit merchant in Fruitville who is trying to buy and sell fruit at the market. He recently had a deal fall through with Cedric Meadowbrook but is currently negotiating with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know my fruit is the best in the market. These apples are crisp and juicy, the pears are sweet as honey, and the bananas are ripe and ready to eat. You won't find better quality anywhere else.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these bananas look fine, but I'm looking for a better price.

          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he staged a grand performance in the family barn, charging the other children a penny to witness his "amazing feats of strength." He insisted on being called "The Mighty Figtree" and demanded applause after each "feat," which consisted mostly of him lifting buckets of water and pretending to wrestle with his pet goat.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from village to village with a cart full of exotic fruits. He developed a flair for storytelling, embellishing the origins and qualities of his wares to entice customers and inflate prices.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a rival fruit merchant who threatened to undercut his prices. Lennon responded by spreading rumors about the rival's fruit being rotten, effectively driving him out of business and solidifying his own dominance in the market.

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree.
